Part E | Sellers decisions make up the supply curve.

Part E is about how market power changes the firm's decisions and how these decisions impact society. So far we've examined how to coordinate groups to minimize opportunity cost. In Part A we motivated this search using the realization that minimizing opportunity cost can make everyone better off simultaneously. In Part B we showed that in some cases markets can be an effective coordination device. In Part C we showed that externalities undermine the efficiency of markets but that we could correct this type of market failure using correctly calibrated Government Policies. In Part D we introduced game theory to help understand the strategic interaction that leads to market failure around Public Goods and Common Resources. We even developed some tools like voting and enforceable permits which can go a long way to minimizing market failure.

This course we charted through economic theory has relied on our loose models of why buyers and sellers choose to interact. In Part A we introduced buyers' preferences with the demand curve and sellers' costs with the supply curve. Before investigating where buyers' preferences come from, in Part E we make the turn to examine the seller's incentives.

To do this we first start with the same production function we used in the Four Quadrant PPF. We input labor and generate an output. Inputs are costly. As we increase inputs we increase output but we also increase cost. This relationship between quantity and costs gives us our core cost measures: Average Total Cost (ATC) and Marginal Cost (MC).

We assume that the seller's aim to maximize their Profits, simply Total Revenue minus Total Cost. And we found that the solution to the Firm's Profit Maximization Problem is to set quantity where MC = MR. The shape of MC depends on the shape of the production function. The shape of MR depends on how much power the firm exerts over the market. Part E is about how this market power changes the firm's decisions and how these decisions impact society.

Reading | Ch. 13 Ch. 15 Ch. 16

Start Part E Cluster 1 by skimming the reading to develop an understanding of the scope of what's being discussed.

Then once you've finished reading, take a look at the practice material, and use the text as a resource when you need help. This way, you know what's most important, get to practicing quickly, and know where to find help when you innevitably get stuck.

Reading | Ch. 17 Ch. 18

Start Part E Cluster 2 by skimming the reading to develop an understanding of the scope of what's being discussed.

Then once you've finished reading, take a look at the practice material, and use the text as a resource when you need help. This way, you know what's most important, get to practicing quickly, and know where to find help when you innevitably get stuck.

Vignette E1

Vignette E1 does Economic Sudoku, building intuition for the relationships between cost variables.

Vignette E2

Vignette E2 covers the transition of a market from Monopoly to Perfect Competition. This requires understanding market structures and being able to describe the impacts of this change using the tools and methods developed in class.

Vignette E3

Vignette E3 examines the impact of a subsidy on a perfectly competitive firm and the market in which they operate in the short run, and uses long run analysis to anticipate long run effects.

Vignette E4

Vignette E4 examines the impact of a new entrant into a Monopolistically Competitive market on a representative firm in the short run and long run.

Vignette E5

Vignette E5 extends the concepts and tools of game theory to examine markets with few sellers, Oligopoly, in which strategic interaction governs the solution to the firm's problem.

Demo E1

Demo E1 is very similar to what you'll see on MiniExam E1. This is a resource for you to use as you'd like. But here's my advice. Start by trying to solve Demo E1 on your own. Then once you've worked through everything as best you're able, use the video and solutions to check your work. You're more than welcome to watch this video first, but you're not going to catch your weak points as easily, which is the main point.

MiniExam E1

MiniExam E1 will be held on March 30 and covers everything covered so far in Part E1. If you understand the concepts and do the work in the Vignettes and Demos, you're going to be in good shape on the MiniExam.

MiniExam E2

MiniExam E2 will be held on April 13 and covers everything in Part E. If you understand the concepts and do the work in the Vignettes and Demos, you're going to be in good shape on the MiniExam.
